Scenes.VoiceOverText: How bad would this have been? Had it not missed the Earth?

Scenes.VoiceOverText: The question is who produced Omuamua?

Scenes.VoiceOverText: On October 19th, 2017, Panstar spotted an object moving rapidly between the stars.
Scenes.Text: On October 19th, 2017, Panstar spotted an object moving rapidly between the stars.

Scenes.VoiceOverText: And this time the usual follow-up measurements showed something completely different.
Scenes.Text: And this time the usual follow-up measurements showed something completely different.

Scenes.VoiceOverText: We had enough data to realize that this object wasn't from our solar system.
Scenes.Text: We had enough data to realize that this object wasn't from our solar system.

Scenes.VoiceOverText: Our own solar system is huge.
Scenes.Text: Our own solar system is huge.

Scenes.VoiceOverText: So even getting a package from the nearest star system, 4.4 light years away,
Scenes.Text: So even getting a package from the nearest star system, 4.4 light years away,

Scenes.VoiceOverText: would take over 50,000 years. So this is a really big deal.

Scenes.VoiceOverText: Some mysterious force, we shout without showing any cometary evaporation,
Scenes.Text: Some mysterious force, we shout without showing any cometary evaporation,

Scenes.VoiceOverText: no rocket effect to push it. The question is, what was pushing it?
Scenes.Text: no rocket effect to push it. The question is, what was pushing it?

Scenes.VoiceOverText: The interstellar visitor entered our solar system from above the plane of the planets,
Scenes.Text: The interstellar visitor entered our solar system from above the plane of the planets,

Scenes.VoiceOverText: coming from the direction of the constellation Lyra,
Scenes.Text: coming from the direction of the constellation Lyra,

Scenes.VoiceOverText: and it passed closest to the Sun on September 9th, passing inside the orbit of Mercury.
